issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in law in holding that the sum of rupees 84,633/- expended by the assessee in obtaining the loan or any part thereof is an allowable expenditure?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in law in holding that the sum of rupees 84,633/- expended by the assessee in obtaining the loan or any part thereof is an allowable expenditure ?

issues.text: Whether the expenditure of Rs. 84,633/- incurred in obtaining the loan is capital expenditure or revenue expenditure?

anchor.surface_text: We must start first with the cases decided by this Court and see what principles have been laid down for distinguishing revenue expenditure from expenditure in the nature of capital expenditure, and especially those cases which dealt with similar problems.

issues.text: Whether the loan obtained constitutes an asset or advantage for the enduring benefit of the business such that the expenditure to obtain it is capital in nature?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court after reviewing various cases, observed If we ask for what purpose the expenditure in the present case was incurred, the only answer must be that it was incurred for the purpose of bringing into existence an asset in the shape of borrowing these Rs. 40 lakhs.

issues.text: Whether the expenditure was laid out wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the assessee's business?
Whether the High Court erred in law in preferring the findings of the Income Tax Officer to that of the Appellate Tribunal?

anchor.surface_text: Before we conclude we must deal with the point raised by Mr. Sastri that the High Court erred in law in preferring the findings of the Income Tax Officer to that of the Appellate Tribunal.

issues.text: Whether there was any material for the finding of the Appellate Tribunal regarding the use of the loan proceeds?

anchor.surface_text: He says that the High Court was right in preferring the findings of the Income Tax Officer on the ground that there was no material for the finding made by the Appellate Tribunal and the finding was based on surmises and material evidence was ignored.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is numberjustification for drawing this distinction in India. As observed by Lord Atkinson in Scottish North American Trust Farmer 1  the interest is, in truth, money paid for the use or hire of an instrument of their trade as much as is the rent paid for their office or the hire paid for a typewriting machine.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in preferring ITO over Tribunal; must accept Tribunal findings unless challenged under S.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: Before we companyclude we must deal with the point raised by Mr. Sastri that the High Court erred in law in preferring the findings of the Income Tax Officer to that of the Appellate Tribunal.

holdings.text: The expenditure of Rs. 84,633/- was not in the nature of capital expenditure and was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the assessee's business.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied tests from prior SC cases (Viscount Cave, commercial expediency); distinguished English cases; purpose of loan irrelevant; allowable under S.10(2)(xv).

holdings.text: The loan obtained is not an asset or advantage of an enduring nature; the expenditure was made for securing the use of money for a certain period; it is irrelevant to consider the object with which the loan was obtained; consequently, the expenditure was revenue expenditure within S. 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: To summarise this part of the case, we are of the opinion that (a) the loan obtained is not an asset or advantage of an enduring nature (b) that the expenditure was made for securing the use of money for a certain period; and (c) that it is irrelevant to consider the object with

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected enduring benefit test application to loans (liability not asset); no distinction between interest and loan costs; criticized reliance on English cases and prior HCs.

holdings.text: The loan obtained is not an asset or advantage of an enduring nature.

anchor.surface_text: To summarise this part of the case, we are of the opinion that (a) the loan obtained is not an asset or advantage of an enduring nature (b) that the expenditure was made for securing the use of money for a certain

holdings.reasoning_summary: Loan is repayable liability; temporary use of money, per Viscount Cave test as applied in prior SC cases.

holdings.text: The expenditure was laid out wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the assessee's business.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide scope of 'purpose of business' includes borrowing as incidental to carrying on business, per Eastern Investments and Malayalam Plantations.

holdings.text: In a reference the High Court must accept the findings of fact made by the Appellate Tribunal unless challenged by an application under s. 66(1) expressly raising the question about the validity of the findings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural rule from prior cases; obiter as not necessary to decide.

holdings.text: The Nagpur Electric Light and Power Co. case was wrongly decided.

anchor.surface_text: With great respect we must hold that this case was wrongly decided.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished obtaining loan from obtaining capital; rejected English-influenced reasoning inapplicable to Indian IT Act.

holdings.text: There is no justification for drawing a distinction in India between interest on loan and expenditure incurred for obtaining the loan.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no justification for drawing this distinction in India. As observed by Lord Atkinson in Scottish North American Trust...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both procure use of money as instrument of trade; analogous to rent or hire.
